SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ________________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The older children had to stay here.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Early buildings were erected of heavy logs & neighbors clubbed together.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. No.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No - varied
PIONEER RESERVATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were there enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many did you usually visit regularly?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Occasionally, rarely, frequently, probably, probably not.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Occasionally, always.

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon or evening.

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually, rarely.

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make patriots" used, or was some other expression common?)

8. The family thought nothing of unexpected visitors dropped in?

9. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

10. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

11. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible; telling what the "meets" were for, and how often they occurred.

12. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. No.

13. Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

only church services

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

practically all of it

9. When was your first community hall built? did not have any.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? yes

How were babies and small children provided for? - mothers did the best they could to enjoy themselves and take care of the babies at the same time.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? in barns

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

many in our district

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? had very little of this

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

card playing & dancing was not looked upon favourably

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

at almost every wedding they scared the daylights out of the newly wed, with the carry other noise making things
